title: My "type" of restaurant...
content:
Wanted to share...

“On your visit to Mistral, make sure to seek out sommelier Kurt Kirschenman, an eminently approachable font of wine knowledge”...

[http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/features/20080409-9999-1f09dining.htm...](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830093108/http:/www.signonsandiego.com/news/features/20080409-9999-1f09dining.html "http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/features/20080409-9999-1f09dining.html")

 [‹ No access to Small Caps in Flash?](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830093108/http:/www.typophile.com/node/44088 "Go to previous forum topic") [Avoiding ignorance: Designing type across cultures ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830093108/http:/www.typophile.com/node/43909 "Go to next forum topic")
author: sii

comments.content:
That’s incredible! Great find! Either it’s a remarkable coincidence or the writer or her editor is a secret type lover.

Does make you wonder what the restaurant’s sign is set in; it seems like too good an opportunity to pass up.

Found their logo (at the bottom of [this PDF](http://web.archive.org/web/20080830093108/http:/www.loewshotels.com/Content/en/Hotels/Coronado-Bay-Resort/DiningLounge/Mistral_Menu_08.pdf)). Sadly, there’s no Mistral to be found; just Bodoni or some other modern.

that makes me very sad. I often call restaurants by their font names with my friends. It’s also fun giving people directions by signage fonts, which is what I thought this article was getting at for a quick second.
